title: 1. Introduction to Python
content:
What is Programming?

Programming is the process of giving instructions to a computer to perform specific tasks. Think of it like a recipe: you write the steps (code), and the computer cooks the meal (execution).

Why Python?

Python is known for being human-readable. It uses indentation to define blocks of code, unlike C++ or Java which use curly braces.

  • Web Dev: Django, Flask
  • Data Science: Pandas, NumPy
  • Automation: Selenium, Scripting

Your First Program

In Python, we use print() to output text to the screen.
code_default:
# Welcome to Python!
# Lines starting with '#' are comments and are ignored by the computer.

print("Hello, World!")
print("I am learning Python!")

title: 2. Variables & Data Types
content:
1. Variables

Variables are used to store data. A variable is created when you assign a value to it.

name = "Alice"
age = 25
height = 5.6

Variable Naming Rules

  • Must start with a letter or underscore (_).
  • Cannot start with a number.
  • Case-sensitive (age, Age and AGE are different).

2. Data Types

Python supports several built-in data types:

TypeDescriptionExample
intWhole numbers10, -5
floatDecimal numbers3.14
strText"Hello"
boolBooleanTrue, False

3. Typecasting & Input

Typecasting: Converting one type to another using int(), float(), or str().

Input: Use input() to take user input (always returns a string).
code_default:
# 1. Variables (Example from Handbook)
name = "Alice"
age = 25
height = 5.6

print(f"Name: {name}, Type: {type(name)}")
print(f"Height: {height}, Type: {type(height)}")

# 2. Typecasting
num_str = "10"
num_int = int(num_str)
print(f"Converted '{num_str}' to {num_int} + 5 = {num_int + 5}")

# 3. Input (Simulated)
print("Enter your name: [User types 'Bob']")
print("Hello, Bob!")

title: 3. Operators & Control Flow
content:
1. Python Operators

Python has 6 main groups of operators:

1. Arithmetic Operators

OperatorNameExample
+Additionx + y
-Subtractionx - y
*Multiplicationx * y
/Divisionx / y
%Modulus (Remainder)x % y
**Exponentiationx ** y
//Floor Divisionx // y

2. Assignment Operators

Used to assign values. Common ones: =, +=, -=, *=.

3. Comparison Operators

Used to compare two values:

  • == (Equal), != (Not Equal)
  • > (Greater), < (Less)
  • >= (Greater/Equal), <= (Less/Equal)

4. Logical Operators

OperatorDescription
andReturns True if both statements are true
orReturns True if one of the statements is true
notReverse the result (True becomes False)

5. Identity & Membership Operators

  • Identity: is, is not (Checks if objects are the same memory location).
  • Membership: in, not in (Checks if a sequence contains a value).

2. Conditional Statements

Python supports logical conditions:

  • if: Executes if the condition is true.
  • elif: (Else If) Checks a new condition if the previous one was false.
  • else: Executes if all previous conditions were false.

[Image of python if else flowchart]

3. Loops

Loops allow you to repeat a block of code.

While Loop

Executes as long as a condition is true.

while i < 6:
    print(i)
    i += 1

For Loop

Used for iterating over a sequence (list, tuple, dictionary, set, or string).

for x in "banana":
    print(x)

Loop Control

  • break: Stops the loop even if the condition is true.
  • continue: Skips the rest of the current iteration.
  • pass: Does nothing (placeholder).
code_default:
# 1. Arithmetic & Assignment
x = 10
x += 5  # Same as x = x + 5
print(f"x is now: {x}")

# 2. Membership Operator
fruits = ["apple", "banana"]
if "apple" in fruits:
    print("Apple is in the list!")

# 3. If-Elif-Else
score = 75
if score >= 90:
    print("Grade: A")
elif score >= 70:
    print("Grade: B")
else:
    print("Grade: C")

# 4. For Loop with Break
print("Searching for 3...")
for i in range(1, 6):
    if i == 3:
        print("Found 3! Stopping loop.")
        break
    print(f"Checking {i}...")

title: 4. Strings: Slicing & Manipulation
content:
1. String Basics

Strings are sequences of characters. In Python, you can use single ('), double ("), or triple (""") quotes for multi-line strings.

Escape Sequences

Use these to insert special characters:

  • \n: New Line
  • \t: Tab
  • \': Single Quote

2. Indexing & Slicing

Python allows you to access individual characters using their position (Index). Indexing starts at 0.

Slicing Syntax: string[start : stop : step]

  • start: Starting index (inclusive).
  • stop: Ending index (exclusive).
  • step: How many characters to jump.

3. Essential String Methods

MethodSyntaxWorking/DescriptionExample (Input -> Output)
.lower()str.lower()Converts all characters to lowercase."PY".lower() -> "py"
.upper()str.upper()Converts all characters to uppercase."hi".upper() -> "HI"
.strip()str.strip()Removes leading/trailing whitespace." x ".strip() -> "x"
.replace()str.replace(o, n)Replaces old substring with new."apple".replace("p", "b") -> "abble"
.split()str.split(sep)Splits string into a List by separator."a-b".split("-") -> ['a', 'b']
.startswith()str.startswith(s)Returns True if string begins with s."Hello".startswith("H") -> True
.count()str.count(s)Counts occurrences of substring s."banana".count("a") -> 3

4. String Formatting (f-Strings)

The modern way to inject variables into strings is using f"...{var}...".
code_default:
# --- 1. Slicing Demo ---
text = "PythonProgramming"

print(f"First 6 chars: {text[:6]}")      # Python
print(f"Last 7 chars: {text[-11:]}")     # Programming
print(f"Every 2nd char: {text[::2]}")    # PtoPormig
print(f"Reverse: {text[::-1]}")          # gnimmargorPnohtyP

# --- 2. Methods Demo ---
email = "  user@example.com  "
clean_email = email.strip()
print(f"Clean Email: '{clean_email}'")

# --- 3. f-Strings Demo ---
name = "Niraj"
version = 3.12
print(f"Hi {name}, you are using Python {version}!")

title: 5. Functions & Scope
content:
1. Anatomy of a Function

A function is a reusable block of code. You define it once and call it whenever needed.

Docstrings

It is best practice to include a Docstring (triple quotes) on the first line to explain what the function does.

2. Parameters vs. Arguments

Parameters: The variables listed in the function definition.
Arguments: The actual values sent to the function when called.

Types of Arguments

TypeSyntaxDescription
Positionalfunc(val1, val2)Arguments must be in the correct order.
Keywordfunc(b=2, a=1)Order doesn't matter if you name the parameters.
Defaultdef f(a=10):Uses the default value if none is provided.
*argsdef f(*args):Accepts a variable number of positional arguments.
**kwargsdef f(**kwargs):Accepts a variable number of keyword arguments.

3. Scope: Local vs. Global

  • Global Scope: Variables created outside a function. They can be accessed anywhere.
  • Local Scope: Variables created inside a function. They only exist while the function is running.
code_default:
# 1. Multiple Return Values
def get_stats(numbers):
    """Returns the sum and average of a list."""
    total = sum(numbers)
    avg = total / len(numbers)
    return total, avg # Returns as a Tuple

s, a = get_stats([10, 20, 30])
print(f"Sum: {s}, Avg: {a}")

# 2. Variable Arguments (*args)
def sum_everything(*args):
    return sum(args)

print(f"Total: {sum_everything(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)})")

# 3. Scope Demonstration
x = "Global" # Global Variable

def my_func():
    x = "Local" # Local Variable
    print(f"Inside function: {x}")

my_func()
print(f"Outside function: {x}")

title: 6. Data Structures: The Complete Guide
content:
1. Lists (Mutable & Ordered)

Used for collections that need to be changed. Syntax: [val1, val2]

MethodSyntaxWorkingExample Output
.append()l.append(x)Adds x to the end.[1, 2, 3]
.extend()l.extend(l2)Joins another list.[1, 2, 3, 4]
.insert()l.insert(i, x)Adds x at index i.['x', 1, 2]
.pop()l.pop(i)Removes/returns item at i.Returns removed item
.remove()l.remove(x)Removes first value x.[2, 3]
.sort()l.sort()Sorts list in-place.[1, 2, 3]
.reverse()l.reverse()Reverses order in-place.[3, 2, 1]

2. Tuples (Immutable & Ordered)

Used for fixed data. Faster than lists. Syntax: (val1, val2)

MethodWorkingExample
.count(x)Counts occurrences of x.(1,1,2).count(1) -> 2
.index(x)Returns first index of x.('a','b').index('b') -> 1

3. Dictionaries (Key-Value Pairs)

Unordered, changeable, and indexed by keys. Syntax: {key: value}

MethodDescriptionExample
.get()Returns value; no error if key missing.d.get('name')
.keys()Returns all keys in dictionary.d.keys()
.values()Returns all values.d.values()
.update()Updates/Adds key-value pairs.d.update({'a':1})
.pop()Removes item with specified key.d.pop('name')

4. Sets (Unique & Unordered)

No duplicate items. Used for math operations. Syntax: {val1, val2}

MethodWorkingExample
.add()Adds unique item.{1}.add(2)
.remove()Removes x; error if missing.{1,2}.remove(1)
.union()Combines unique items from two sets.{1}.union({2})
.intersection()Finds common items.{1,2}.intersection({2})
code_default:
# --- Comprehensive Data Structure Demo ---

# 1. List Operations
my_list = [3, 1, 2]
my_list.append(4)
my_list.sort()
print(f"List: {my_list}")

# 2. Dictionary Operations
user = {"name": "Niraj", "age": 25}
user.update({"city": "Mumbai"})
print(f"User: {user}")

# 3. Set Operations (Removing Duplicates)
raw = [1, 2, 2, 3, 4, 4, 4]
unique = list(set(raw))
print(f"Unique values: {unique}")

# 4. Tuple (Attempting change throws error)
tpl = (10, 20)
try:
    tpl[0] = 5
except TypeError:
    print("Tuple is immutable and cannot be changed!")

title: 7. Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)
content:
1. Classes & The Constructor

A Class is a blueprint. An Object is an instance. The self parameter represents the instance of the object itself.

The Constructor: __init__

Used to initialize attributes. Example: self.brand = brand.

2. The 4 Pillars of OOP

I. Inheritance & Overriding

Allows a child class to derive features from a parent. Method Overriding occurs when a child provides a specific implementation of a method already defined by its parent.

super().__init__() # Calls parent constructor

II. Encapsulation (Data Hiding)

Restricts direct access to data. We use Getters and Setters to modify private variables safely.

  • self._protected: Suggests internal use.
  • self.__private: Triggers name mangling to prevent outside access.

III. Polymorphism

The same function name can be used for different types. This is often achieved through Duck Typing in Python.

IV. Abstraction

Hiding complexity by using Abstract Base Classes (ABC). You define a template that must be followed by children but cannot be instantiated itself.

3. Magic (Dunder) Methods

MethodDescriptionTrigger
__str__Human-readable stringprint(obj)
__len__Returns object lengthlen(obj)
__del__Destructor (cleanup)del obj

title: 8. Advanced Python Concepts
content:
1. Exception Handling

Prevent crashes using try-except blocks.

try:
    x = 10 / 0
except ZeroDivisionError:
    print("Can't divide by zero!")
finally:
    print("Always runs")

2. Magic Methods (Dunder)

Special methods with double underscores that define object behavior.

MethodActionExample Trigger
__init__Constructorobj = Class()
__str__String Repprint(obj)
__add__Operator +obj1 + obj2
__len__Lengthlen(obj)

3. Flexible Arguments (*args & **kwargs)

Allows functions to accept unlimited arguments.

  • *args: Passes arguments as a Tuple .
  • **kwargs: Passes arguments as a Dictionary.

4. Decorators

Wrappers that modify a function's behavior without changing its code. Use the @ syntax.

5. Walrus Operator (:=)

Assigns values inside an expression (Python 3.8+).
if (n := len(list)) > 10: ...

title: 9. File I/O & Error Handling
content:
1. Working with Files

Python makes it easy to read and write files. The with statement is the 'gold standard' because it automatically closes the file, even if an error occurs.

File Access Modes

ModeDescriptionAction
'r'Read OnlyError if file doesn't exist.
'w'Write OnlyCreates file or overwrites existing content.
'a'AppendAdds data to the end of the file.
'rb' / 'wb'Binary ModeUsed for images, PDFs, and non-text files.

2. Reading Techniques

  • f.read(): Reads the entire file as a single string.
  • f.readline(): Reads one line at a time.
  • f.readlines(): Returns a list where each item is a line.

3. Exception Handling (Try-Except)

To prevent your app from crashing when a file is missing, always wrap file operations in a try-except block.

title: 10. Modules, PIP & Environments
content:
1. Modules & Packages

A Module is a file containing Python code. A Package is a collection of modules. You use import to bring this code into your project.

Import Variations

import math          # Import everything
from math import pi  # Import specific item
import numpy as np   # Import with alias

2. PIP: The Package Manager

PIP is used to download libraries from the Python Package Index (PyPI). Useful commands:

  • pip install library_name: Install a package.
  • pip list: See all installed packages.
  • pip freeze > requirements.txt: Save project dependencies.

3. Virtual Environments (venv)

Different projects may need different versions of the same library. A Virtual Environment is an isolated folder that keeps your project's libraries separate from the rest of your computer.

python -m venv myenv    # Create environment
source myenv/activate  # Activate (Mac/Linux)
myenv\Scripts\activate # Activate (Windows)
code_default:
import random
import os
from datetime import datetime

# Using Standard Libraries
print(f"Current Directory: {os.getcwd()}")
print(f"Current Time: {datetime.now()}")

# Using Random
options = ["Success", "Failure", "Retry"]
result = random.choice(options)
print(f"Operation Result: {result}")
